TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit Log extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides a property and methods for writing event and exception information to the application's log listeners.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `My.Application.Log` object provides a straightforward entry point from which to access the [!INCLUDE[dnprdnshort](~/add/includes/dnprdnshort-md.md)]'s logging services. The `WriteEntry` and `WriteException` methods write messages to the application's log listeners. The listeners can be configured by the application's configuration file. For more information, see [Walkthrough: Changing Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md) and [Working with Application Logs](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The `My.Application.Log` object is available only for client applications. For Web applications, use `My.Log`. For more information, see <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.AspLog>.
The following table lists examples of tasks involving the `My.Application.Log` object.
|To|See| |--------|---------| |Write event information to the application's log listeners|[How to: Write Log Messages](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)| |Write exception information to the application's log listeners|[How to: Log Exceptions](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)| |Determine where `My.Application.Log` writes information|[Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)|
## Examples This example shows how to use the `My.Application.Log.WriteEntry` method to log tracing information. For more information, see [How to: Write Log Messages](../Topic/How%20to:%20Write%20Log%20Messages%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md).
[!code-vb[VbVbalrMyApplicationLog#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/VbVbalrMyApplicationLog/Form1.vb#11)]

MemberSignature.Value: public Log ();
.method public specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

.method public specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string name) cil managed

Docs.param: <xref:System.String>. The name to give to the <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.Log.TraceSource%2A> property object.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.FileLogTraceListener DefaultFileLogWriter { get; }
.property instance class Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.FileLogTraceListener DefaultFileLogWriter

Docs.summary: Gets the file the object that underlies the object.
Docs.value: Returns the object that underlies the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property to determine the current configuration of the <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.FileLogTraceListener> object.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.

Docs.permission: Controls the ability to access files and folders. Associated enumeration: .

MemberSignature.Value: protected virtual void InitializeWithDefaultsSinceNoConfigExists ();
.method familyorassemblynewslot virtual instance void InitializeWithDefaultsSinceNoConfigExists() cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates a new object and adds it to the <xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceSource.Listeners%2A> collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method creates a new <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.FileLogTraceListener>, sets its name to `FileLog`, and configures it to log messages with severity level <xref:System.Diagnostics.SourceLevels> and greater. The new <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.FileLogTraceListener> object is then added to the <xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceSource.Listeners%2A> collection.
The <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.Log.%23ctor%2A> calls the method if the <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.Logging.Log.TraceSource%2A> property has not been configured. The trace source can be configured in the application's configuration file.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Diagnostics.TraceSource TraceSource { get; }
.property instance class System.Diagnostics.TraceSource TraceSource

Docs.summary: Gets to the object that underlies the object.
Docs.value: Returns the object that underlies the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property to determine the current configuration of the `Log` object.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
This is an advanced member; it does not show in IntelliSense unless you select the **All** tab.
The following table lists an example of a task involving the `TraceSource` property.
|To|See| |--------|---------| |Get information for each of the `Log` object's log listeners.|[Troubleshooting: Log Listeners](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)|
## Availability by Project Type
|Project type|Available| |------------------|---------------| |Windows Application|**Yes**| |Class Library|**Yes**| |Console Application|**Yes**| |Windows Control Library|**Yes**| |Web Control Library|No| |Windows Service|**Yes**| |Web Site|**Yes**|

MemberSignature.Value: public void WriteEntry (string message);
.method public instance void WriteEntry(string message) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. The message to log. If `message` is , an empty string is used.
Docs.summary: Writes a message to the application's log listeners.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `WriteEntry` method writes a message to the application's event log listeners.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
To learn which log listeners receive the `WriteEntry` method's messages, see [Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). You can change default log listeners. For more information, see [Working with Application Logs](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
For overloads that do not take the `id` argument, the `id` written to the log is defined by the following table.
|`severity`|Default `id`| |----------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|0| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|1| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|2| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|3| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|4| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|5| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|6| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|7| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|8| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|9|
The following table lists examples of tasks involving the `WriteEntry` method.
|To|See| |--------|---------| |Write event information to the application's log listeners|[How to: Write Log Messages](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)| |Determine where `Log` writes information|[Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](../Topic/Walkthrough:%20Determining%20Where%20My.Application.Log%20Writes%20Information%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md)|
## Availability by Project Type
|Project type|Available| |------------------|---------------| |Windows Application|**Yes**| |Class Library|**Yes**| |Console Application|**Yes**| |Windows Control Library|**Yes**| |Web Control Library|No| |Windows Service|**Yes**| |Web Site|**Yes**|
## Examples This example shows how to use the `My.Application.Log.WriteEntry` method to log tracing information. For more information, see [How to: Write Log Messages](../Topic/How%20to:%20Write%20Log%20Messages%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md).
[!code-vb[VbVbalrMyApplicationLog#11](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/VbVbalrMyApplicationLog/Form1.vb#11)]
This code example can run only within a client application. Change `My.Application.Log.WriteEntry` to `My.Log.WriteEntry` for Web applications.

Docs.exception: Code with partial trust calls the method, but writes to an event log listener that requires full trust.
Docs.permission: Controls the ability to access files and folders. Associated enumeration: .

MemberSignature.Value: public void WriteEntry (string message, System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity);
.method public instance void WriteEntry(string message, valuetype System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. The message to log. If `message` is , an empty string is used.
The type of message. By default, .
Docs.summary: Writes a message to the application's log listeners.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `WriteEntry` method writes a message to the application's event log listeners.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
To learn which log listeners receive the `WriteEntry` method's messages, see [Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). You can change default log listeners. For more information, see [Working with Application Logs](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
For overloads that do not take the `id` argument, the `id` written to the log is defined by the following table.
|`severity`|Default `id`| |----------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|0| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|1| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|2| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|3| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|4| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|5| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|6| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|7| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|8| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|9|

## Examples This example shows how to use the `My.Application.Log.WriteEntry` method to log tracing information. For more information, see [How to: Write Log Messages](../Topic/How%20to:%20Write%20Log%20Messages%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md).

Code with partial trust calls the method, but writes to an event log listener that requires full trust.
Docs.permission: Controls the ability to access files and folders. Associated enumeration: .

MemberSignature.Value: public void WriteEntry (string message, System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity, int id);
.method public instance void WriteEntry(string message, valuetype System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity, int32 id) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. The message to log. If `message` is , an empty string is used.
The type of message. By default, .
Message identifier, typically used for correlation. By default, related to `entryType` as described in the table.

## Remarks The `WriteEntry` method writes a message to the application's event log listeners.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
To learn which log listeners receive the `WriteEntry` method's messages, see [Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). MemberSignature.Value: public void WriteException (Exception ex);
.method public instance void WriteException(class System.Exception ex) cil managed

Docs.summary: Writes exception information to the application's log listeners.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `WriteException` method writes the information contained in an exception to the application's event log listeners.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
To learn which log listeners receive the `WriteException` method's messages, see [Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). You can change default log listeners. For more information, see [Working with Application Logs](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
For overloads that do not take the `id` argument, the identifier written to the log is defined by the following table.
|`severity`|Default `id`| |----------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|0| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|1| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|2| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|3| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|4| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|5| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|6| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|7| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|8| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|9|
The following table lists examples of tasks involving the `WriteException` method.
|To|See| |--------|---------| |Write exception information to the application's event log listeners.|[How to: Log Exceptions](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)| |Determine where `Log` writes information.|[Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](../Topic/Walkthrough:%20Determining%20Where%20My.Application.Log%20Writes%20Information%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md)|
## Availability by Project Type
|Project type|Available| |------------------|---------------| |Windows Application|**Yes**| |Class Library|**Yes**| |Console Application|**Yes**| |Windows Control Library|**Yes**| |Web Control Library|No| |Windows Service|**Yes**| |Web Site|**Yes**|
## Examples This example shows how to use the `My.Application.Log.WriteException` method to log exceptions. Uncomment the `Dim` and `MsgBox` lines to cause a <xref:System.NullReferenceException> exception. For more information, see [How to: Log Exceptions](../Topic/How%20to:%20Log%20Exceptions%20in%20Visual%20Basic.md).
[!code-vb[VbVbalrMyApplicationLog#10](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/VbVbalrMyApplicationLog/Form1.vb#10)]
This code example can run only within a client application. Change `My.Application.Log.WriteException` to `My.Log.WriteException` for Web applications.

Docs.exception: Code with partial trust calls the method, but writes to an event log listener that requires full trust.
Docs.permission: Controls the ability to access files and folders. Associated enumeration: .

MemberSignature.Value: public void WriteException (Exception ex, System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity, string additionalInfo);
.method public instance void WriteException(class System.Exception ex, valuetype System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType severity, string additionalInfo) cil managed

Docs.param: The type of message. By default, .
String to append to the message. By default, this is an empty string.
Docs.summary: Writes exception information to the application's log listeners.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `WriteException` method writes the information contained in an exception to the application's event log listeners.
In client applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Application.Log` object. In Web applications, the `Log` object is available through the `My.Log` object.
To learn which log listeners receive the `WriteException` method's messages, see [Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md). You can change default log listeners. For more information, see [Working with Application Logs](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
For overloads that do not take the `id` argument, the identifier written to the log is defined by the following table.
|`severity`|Default `id`| |----------------|------------------| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|0| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|1| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|2| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|3| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|4| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|5| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|6| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|7| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|8| |<xref:System.Diagnostics.TraceEventType>|9|
The following table lists examples of tasks involving the `WriteException` method.
|To|See| |--------|---------| |Write exception information to the application's event log listeners.|[How to: Log Exceptions](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)| |Determine where `Log` writes information.|[Walkthrough: Determining Where My.Application.Log Writes Information](../Topic/Walkthrough:%20Determining%20Where%20My.Application.Log%20Writes%20Information%20\(Visual%20Basic\).md)|
## Availability by Project Type
|Project type|Available| |------------------|---------------| |Windows Application|**Yes**| |Class Library|**Yes**| |Console Application|**Yes**| |Windows Control Library|**Yes**| |Web Control Library|No| |Windows Service|**Yes**| |Web Site|**Yes**|
## Examples This example shows how to use the `My.Application.Log.WriteException` method to log exceptions. Uncomment the `Dim` and `MsgBox` lines to cause a <xref:System.NullReferenceException> exception. For more information, see [How to: Log Exceptions](../Topic/How%20to:%20Log%20Exceptions%20in%20Visual%20Basic.md).
